resources.string: The objective of the game is to rearrange the tiles such that they are arranged 1 through 8 as shown below:
In order to play; move the phone in the direction in which you want to move the tile into the blank space.
For example, in the situation shown below, Move the ‘2 tile’ up by moving the phone up.
The beginning of every motion must be done in a strong but swift motion immediately followed by a return to center. After each move, you must wait at center for 2 seconds before continuing.
If stuck, for a hint move the phone up and down in the z-direction.
To undo a move, press the undo button.

In addition to the motion input, we have also added in the option to interface with the game by swiping on each of the tiles. This maintains the cognitive load of our, but decreases the physical requirements out of the user. This input option can be by accessing the Settings page from the 8-Puzzle gameplay screen.
The objective of the game is to solve the provided algebra problems within the allotted time by using either motion or the touch screen interface.
To answer the question, input numbers based on the descriptions below:

After you have inputted the desired number, press the submit button. If your answer is correct you will move on to the next level, otherwise press the footer until it is no longer red (only one tap should be needed) and then re-enter a new solution.

In addition, you may also press the numbers on the provided keypad to answer. To delete a number, press the delete button. To get another problem, press reset. Resetting a question will be considered wrong and will reset your score back to 0.
1, move the phone in the North West direction.
3, move the phone in the North East direction.
5, move the phone away from you.
7, move the phone in the South West direction.
9, move the phone in the South East direction.
Select the Magic Squares type under settings.
The rules of this game are to arrange the numbers from 1 to n^2 such that the sum of the entries of any row, any column or any main diagonal is the same.
Hint: The sum should be n(n^2+1)/2.
